hints_html:
Recall that the functions

\[\begin{aligned} \displaystyle{}e^{2\pi{}inx/L}\end{aligned}\]

are an orthogonal basis for square integrable functions, i.e.

\[\begin{aligned} \int_0^Le^{2\pi{}inx/L}e^{-2\pi{}imx/L}\textrm{d}x=\begin{cases} L,\qquad{}n=m\\ 0,\qquad{}n\neq{}m \end{cases}\end{aligned}\]

How can we use this orthogonality to get the coefficients in the series?

question: 6 (a)
sols_html:
Let

\[\begin{aligned} \displaystyle{}e_n(x)=e^{2\pi{}inx}\end{aligned}\]

so that we want \(c_i\) such that

\[\begin{aligned} x=\sum_{i=-\infty}^\infty{}c_ie_i(x).\end{aligned}\]

From Hint 1 (and setting L=1) we have that \(e_n\) are orthogonal i.e.,

\[\begin{aligned} \int_0^1e_n(x)\overline{e_m}(x)\textrm{d}x=\begin{cases} 1,\qquad{}n=m\\ 0,\qquad{}n\neq{}m \end{cases}\end{aligned}\]

where the overbar indicates the complex conjugate

\[\begin{aligned} \displaystyle{}\overline{e_n}(x)=e^{-2\pi{}inx}.\end{aligned}\]

We can get the coefficients of \(x\) using this orthogonality. Take the inner product with each \(e_{n}(x)\)

\[\begin{aligned} \langle e_{n},x \rangle = \sum_{i=-\infty}^{\infty} c_{i} \langle e_{n},e_{i} \rangle = c_{n} \langle e_{n},e_{n} \rangle =c_{n}\end{aligned}\]

\[\begin{aligned} c_{n} = \int_{0}^{1} e^{-2\pi inx}xdx.\end{aligned}\]

If \(n\neq 0,\) we use integration by parts

\[\begin{aligned} \int udv=uv-\int vdu\end{aligned}\]

with \(u = x\), \(dv = e^{-2\pi inx}dx\) to obtain

\[\begin{aligned} c_{n} &= \left [\frac{x}{-2\pi in} e^{-2\pi inx} \right ]^{1}_{0} + \int_{0}^{1} \frac{1}{2\pi in} e^{-2\pi inx}dx \\ &= \left [-\frac{x}{2\pi in} e^{-2\pi inx} - \frac{1}{4\pi^{2} i^{2}n^{2}} e^{-2\pi inx} \right ]^{1}_{0} \\ &= \left [-\frac{x}{2\pi in} e^{-2\pi inx} + \frac{1}{4\pi^{2}n^{2}} e^{-2\pi inx} \right ]^{1}_{0} \\ &= \left [\left(\frac{1}{4\pi^{2}n^{2}}-\frac{x}{2\pi in} \right) e^{-2\pi inx} \right ]^{1}_{0} \\ &= \left [\left(\frac{1}{4\pi^{2}n^{2}}-\frac{1}{2\pi in} \right) e^{-2\pi in(1)} \right ]-\left [\left(\frac{1}{4\pi^{2}n^{2}}-0 \right) e^{-2\pi in(0)} \right ] \\ &= \left(\frac{1}{4\pi^{2}n^{2}}-\frac{1}{2\pi in} \right) e^{-2\pi in}- \frac{1}{4\pi^{2}n^{2}} \\ &= \left(\frac{1}{4\pi^{2}n^{2}}-\frac{1}{2\pi in} \right) (1)- \frac{1}{4\pi^{2}n^{2}} \\ &=-\frac{1}{2\pi in}\\ &=\frac{i}{2\pi{}n}\end{aligned}\]

Here we see the importance of having \(n\neq0\), otherwise the coefficient diverges using this formula. If n = 0,

\[\begin{aligned} c_{0} = \int_{0}^{1} f(x)dx = \left [\frac{1}{2}x^{2} \right ]^{1}_{0}= \frac{1}{2}\end{aligned}\]

Therefore, we have all the coefficients for the series.

</math>

so that we want <math>c_i</math> such that

:<math>
x=\sum_{i=-\infty}^\infty{}c_ie_i(x).
</math>

From [[Science:Math_Exam_Resources/Courses/MATH307/December_2010/Question_06_(a)/Hint_1|Hint 1]] (and setting L=1) we have that <math>e_n</math> are orthogonal i.e.,

:<math>

1,\qquad{}n=m\\
0,\qquad{}n\neq{}m
\end{cases}
</math>

where the overbar indicates the complex conjugate

:<math>
\displaystyle{}\overline{e_n}(x)=e^{-2\pi{}inx}.
</math>

We can get the coefficients of <math>x</math> using this orthogonality. Take the inner product with each <math>e_{n}(x)</math>

:<math> \langle e_{n},x \rangle = \sum_{i=-\infty}^{\infty} c_{i} \langle e_{n},e_{i} \rangle = c_{n} \langle e_{n},e_{n} \rangle =c_{n}</math>

:<math>c_{n} = \int_{0}^{1} e^{-2\pi inx}xdx</math>.

If <math>n\neq 0,</math> we use integration by parts: <math>\int udv=uv-\int vdu</math> with <math>u = x</math>, <math>dv = e^{-2\pi inx}dx</math> to obtain

:<math> \begin{align}
c_{n} &= \left [\frac{x}{-2\pi in} e^{-2\pi inx} \right ]^{1}_{0} + \int_{0}^{1} \frac{1}{2\pi in} e^{-2\pi inx}dx \\
&= \left [-\frac{x}{2\pi in} e^{-2\pi inx} - \frac{1}{4\pi^{2} i^{2}n^{2}} e^{-2\pi inx} \right ]^{1}_{0} \\
&= \left [-\frac{x}{2\pi in} e^{-2\pi inx} + \frac{1}{4\pi^{2}n^{2}} e^{-2\pi inx} \right ]^{1}_{0} \\
&= \left [\left(\frac{1}{4\pi^{2}n^{2}}-\frac{x}{2\pi in} \right) e^{-2\pi inx} \right ]^{1}_{0} \\
&= \left [\left(\frac{1}{4\pi^{2}n^{2}}-\frac{1}{2\pi in} \right) e^{-2\pi in(1)} \right ]-\left [\left(\frac{1}{4\pi^{2}n^{2}}-0 \right) e^{-2\pi in(0)} \right ] \\
&= \left(\frac{1}{4\pi^{2}n^{2}}-\frac{1}{2\pi in} \right) e^{-2\pi in}- \frac{1}{4\pi^{2}n^{2}} \\
&= \left(\frac{1}{4\pi^{2}n^{2}}-\frac{1}{2\pi in} \right) (1)- \frac{1}{4\pi^{2}n^{2}} \\
&=-\frac{1}{2\pi in}\\
&=\frac{i}{2\pi{}n}
\end{align}</math>

Here we see the importance of having <math>n\neq0</math>, otherwise the coefficient diverges using this formula.  If ''n = 0'',

:<math>c_{0} = \int_{0}^{1} f(x)dx = \left [\frac{1}{2}x^{2} \right ]^{1}_{0}= \frac{1}{2}</math>

Therefore, we have all the coefficients for the series.
